PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Stewart Pearce
Address: 1842 Broadmoor Street, Victoria, B.C.
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1893
Where did you set up housekeeping? At Farwell's farm near Victoria
Where had you been living before that? In Butler valley of British Columbia
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 37 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a year, mostly winter months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? (Please list them in the accompanying questionnaire.)

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, sometimes served with sugar but no milk.

Dinner: Sow belly, ham, hard-boiled eggs, tea, bread, and butter.

Supper: Sow belly with beans, perhaps cooked prime chicken or ducks, roasted apples, potatoes if available, pudding or sweets, tea and bread.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Beef, hash, stuffed onions, boiled 2½ hours by myself, apple pie (considered rich and something to talk about), cake made from rice (really) ground in the coffee grinder. Potatoes, a gallon of Hudson Bay whey.

H.C. Bilton, Walter, Walter Humphrey, and the writer.

Lithgow Wilson, Thomas and Jackson, all members of the N.W.M.P. detachment stationed in the above vicinity, ate freely of the whey, not too well to this country, being accustomed to the better fare.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

As a liberal, since from the supply of provisions was regularly provided for the members' consumption, no serious lack of food was encountered. Maple butter being the source of supply at a distance of 45 miles from the ranch, to reach which the heavy snows often covered summit of the Cypress Hills, had to be negotiated if the trip was made in the winter; hence the necessity of having in a generous store of food previously to the Cypress Hills crossing being snow-bound.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Modern complexities of often chemically preserved food compound within simple (consequently wealth promoting) diets of the past to be regarded as the motivation of many present day physical complications and illnesses.
